awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of Forest Fragment Size, Shape, and Structure on Rainfall Redistribution and Solute Flux in Urban Settings
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will investigate the ways in which the shape and structural characteristics of urban forest fragments affect the cycling of water and solutes in wooded ecosystems of metropolitan areas.  The doctoral student will seek to disentangle the complex relationship between forest fragmentation and the ecosystem services they can provide by establishing a clearer understanding of the differences in water and solute flux among forest fragments with varying canopy structure and location along an urban-to-rural land-use gradient.  This project will enhance basic knowledge of the forms into which precipitation is partitioned when it falls in forest fragments, such as water that is intercepted in forest canopies, water that falls to the ground from leaves (throughfall), and water that flows down the trunks and stems of plants (stemflow).  Project findings should help assess the chemistry of throughfall and stemflow in relation to fragment size and shape, location, and structural characteristics.  Through these and other  measurements, this project will help develop a more accurate quantification of ecosystem services provided by urban forest fragments, particularly the reduction of stormwater runoff and the modification of solute transport to ground- and surface-water pools.  In addition to enhancing basic understanding, the project will provide new insights into methods to manage forest fragments for the conservation of green/forested space in urbanizing areas. Data from this work will be made readily available to the public via the Delaware Environmental Monitoring and Analysis Center web portal for those interested in improving the management of urban green spaces.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The overarching question of this research is: How does the hydrological function of urban forest fragments (namely the partitioning of precipitation into throughfall and stemflow, and the leaching and cycling of solutes) vary among forest fragments within the city and along an urban-rural gradient?  This student will investigate interception losses in five forest fragments in Wilmington, Delaware, and along an urban-to-rural gradient in that metropolitan area in order to understand its effect on water inputs and the chemical signature of throughfall and stemflow.  She will employ field methods in forest hydrology and hydrochemical laboratory analyses to quantify both precipitation partitioning and solute chemistry of throughfall and stemflow.  Additional analyses will elucidate the dynamic nature of precipitation partitioning over space and through time in relation to land use.

por.por_cntn:
Urban forest fragments often comprise a sizeable proportion of metropolitan-area forest cover, and as such, are relied upon for various ecosystem services. These include, but are not limited to, air quality control through the capture of harmful airborne particulate matter, flood risk reduction through the process of rainfall interception, and urban heat island mitigation through the distributed provision of shade-induced cooling. Collectively, these and other ecosystem services produced by the urban canopy help to provide a quality of life that is sustainably suitable for metropolitan residents, in addition to the various plant and animal species that also inhabit urbanized areas. Despite the critical societal and ecological importance of these remnant woodlots, much remains unknown about the hydrologically-driven processes that promote elemental cycling within them. In this Wilmington, Delaware, USA-based study, we utilized field and laboratory research methods to determine the linkages between the physical and geographic characteristics of urban forest fragments (e.g., species composition, location within a metropolitan region), and the transport of water and solutes both to and within them. This was partly achieved through the novel simultaneous use of two metrics designed to quantitatively characterize the chemical enrichment of precipitation interacting with urban forest cover and its subsequent transport  to forest soils via throughfall (water that passes through the canopy) and stemflow (water that drains over the exterior of the tree trunk). The first metric compares the flux-based stemflow enrichment with throughfall per unit trunk basal area, whereas the second compares the flux-based enrichment of stemflow to rainfall per unit trunk basal area.

The urban fragments in this study intercepted an average 25% of incident rainfall, thereby providing important sizeable, localized hotspots of runoff reduction and flood risk mitigation. For K, Ca, Mg, Mn, S, and NO3, the median flux-based enrichment ratios for stemflow calculated in relation to throughfall ranged from 2.8 (Mg) to 63.8 (Mn). When calculated in relation to gross rainfall, median flux-based stemflow enrichment ratios exhibited a similar range with Mn, once again, being most enriched. There were, however, some significant differences between these two flux-based enrichment ratios for a given tree species with respect to the location of an urban remnant within the city as well as between urban and exurban sites. Both metrics indicate that the locally concentrated solute fluxes transported via stemflow notably exceed those transported via throughfall and open precipitation. Additionally, solute fluxes generated by relatively smooth-barked trees were thirty-two times higher than those produced by rough-barked trees for K, with comparatively high yields also observed for Ca, Mg, Mn, S, and NO3. These observations confirm the significant impact of species heterogeneity on the spatial allocation of water and nutrients within urban woodlots.

These findings provide new insight into (a) the role urban forest fragments serve in capturing and redistributing precipitation and nutrients within metropolitan regions, and (b) the spatial variability these fluxes display within individual urban woodlots. This quantifying of water and solute fluxes within the urban fragments may be of benefit to urban foresters and land managers who intend to implement more strategic, data-driven approaches to urban forest conservation, management, and expansion – specifically those approaches designed to maximize hydrologic and hydrochemical ecosystem service provision by the urban canopy.

The broader impacts of this work were also characterized by a series of community engagement activities led by the graduate researcher and designed to connect residents within the study region with the project’s core goals and potential utility in local water resource management. In conjunction with municipal natural resource managers and region-wide multi-agency partnerships, the graduate researcher implemented interactive educational outreach initiatives in which diverse groups of K-12 students were introduced to concepts relating urban forestry and urban hydrology. Additionally, the graduate research independently hosted a town hall-style meeting during which adult community members were able to engage in dynamic dialogue about the project and its related implications for advancing urban forestry science and practice within the academy, city, and broader scales of impact. The project further provided the graduate researcher the opportunity to train five cohorts of undergraduate scholars in field and laboratory techniques in forest hydrology and biogeochemistry, with this training further supported and aided by an ongoing partnership with an urban forest administrator whose work is based within the study region.

A manuscript detailing some of the major findings of this study is under review with Urban Forestry and Urban Greening. Additional manuscripts are in preparation for Landscape and Urban Planning and Urban Ecosystems.
